display_asset.caption: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

summaries.body: The United States is still in danger of losing the war on AIDS, according to Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
A committee at Harvard will consider replacing the law school's logo, which is based on the family crest of a slave owner, following student complaints.

display_asset.caption: President Obama's State of the Union address on Jan. 20, 2015.

summaries.body: President Obama will deliver his final State of the Union address on Jan. 12, an early date designed in part to get out of the way of the presidential primary season.

display_asset.caption: At the Gotham Awards, the “Spotlight” winners included Liev Schreiber, left, the director Tom McCarthy, Rachel McAdams and John Slattery.

summaries.body: "Spotlight," about The Boston Globe's investigation into priests' sexual abuse of children, was the best-feature winner at the IFP Gotham Independent Film Awards.
About a dozen wooden fishing boats, some with dead bodies on board, have washed ashore in Japan in recent weeks.
Starting Tuesday, diners at chain restaurants in New York will see warnings on menus for high-salt items, under a rule believed to be the first of its kind in the country.

display_asset.caption: Lance Cpl. Joseph Scott Pemberton of the United States Marines, center, being escorted into court in Olongapo City, Philippines, on Tuesday.

summaries.body: A court in the Philippines convicted a United States Marine, Lance Cpl. Joseph Scott Pemberton, of homicide in the killing of a transgender woman last year.

display_asset.caption: Robert L. Dear Jr., right, appeared in court via live video with his public defender, Dan King, on Monday in Colorado Springs.

summaries.body: Robert L. Dear Jr., the man accused of fatally shooting three people at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs, made his first court appearance on Monday.

display_asset.credit: David Azia for The New York Times

summaries.body: At 22, Vince Staples is a rap star who is “not a fan of rap culture,” which he sees as one of many systems that set black people against one another.
To prevent shortages, Russia said it would wait several weeks to carry out a ban on produce from Turkey, which was a response to the shooting down of a Russian warplane.
A new study suggests that it is rare for any individual brain to be male or female, and that most contain a mixed bag of traits associated with both sexes.
Kobe Bryant did more of everything than almost anyone. He is in the Lakers’ top five in rebounds, assists, steals, blocks, free throws, 3-pointers, fouls and turnovers.

display_asset.credit: Photo by Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

summaries.body: Chinese families are looking for a safe place to invest their renminbi. American real estate is an increasingly popular destination for their cash.
Broadway attendance broke records during Thanksgiving week as 12 shows brought in more than $1 million apiece.

display_asset.credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

summaries.body: Hafthor Julius Bjornsson, an Icelandic strongman who plays a villain called the Mountain on HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” broke his own world record for the 33-pound keg toss.
The Hong Kong company VTech said that personal information of 5 million people had been compromised, including children's names and birthdays.
Amazon released a video on Sunday that shows off its prototype delivery drone and underlines the retailer's ambitions to sell more Prime subscriptions.

display_asset.caption: A post from the Tumblr The Last Message Received.

summaries.body: With her popular Tumblr projects, an Ohio teenager has collected thousands of sad messages — and one book deal — from people on the Internet.

display_asset.caption: Eldzier Cortor (1916-2015), a painter and printmaker, was part of a generation of black artists whose work was overlooked by many institutions but is now being recognized.
display_asset.credit: Produced by By DAMON WINTER, BEN LAFFIN and SOO-JEONG KANG
display_asset.title: Painting the 20th Century

summaries.body: Eldzier Cortor, a painter and printmaker, was part of a generation of black artists whose work was overlooked by many institutions but is now being recognized.
Mike Allen, Politico’s chief White House correspondent, has apologized for once offering to interview Chelsea Clinton using prearranged questions.
Dr. Jack Kevorkian’s files on assisted suicides, which include videos of patients requesting help to die, have been made public by his alma mater, the University of Michigan.

display_asset.caption: Scientists analyzed the process by watching cracks spread through a bursting balloon in slow motion.
display_asset.credit: Produced by By DAVID FRANK and JAMES GORMAN
display_asset.title: ScienceTake | How Balloons Pop

summaries.body: How your holiday balloons pop. Scientists analyzed the process by watching cracks spread through bursting balloons in slow motion.

display_asset.caption: New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in April in front of the LGBT Community Center in Manhattan, will discuss the state's gains in reducing H.I.V. infections on Tuesday.

summaries.body: In a speech for World AIDS Day on Tuesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to highlight New York's progress in its campaign to end the AIDS epidemic by 2020.

display_asset.caption: A mural in Moscow picturing “Star Wars” stormtroopers.

summaries.body: For the Walt Disney Company, movies — particularly “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” —  have been diverting investors' attention from ESPN's woes.
In Finland, ranking schools against one another is discouraged by education officials who think the practice will lead inexorably to inequality.

display_asset.caption: Rebekah Brooks leaving a London court in 2012. Ms. Brooks was acquitted of various crimes in 2014 and then basically reinstated to her old job as chief executive of News UK.

summaries.body: The unspoken laws of British tabloids have been reconfigured years after a phone-hacking scandal exposed a pattern of illicit information-gathering at The News of the World.
The Irish singer Sinead O'Connor has posted a possible suicide note on Facebook and is reported to be receiving medical attention.
Marco Rubio has run for office six times and has never lost an election, partly thanks to what a New Yorker writer suggests is his flexible political ideology.

display_asset.caption: A tribute to the album cover for Rhymefest’s “Man in the Mirror.”

summaries.body: Hello again, Rhymefest and Iron Man. Marvel will release free reprints of variant comic book covers that reinterpret hip-hop album covers with Marvel characters.
The University of Chicago has canceled all classes and activities on its main campus Monday because of a specific anonymous threat of gun violence.
